reviewText:
InMind VR is a Rail shooter demo that takes place inside a human brain.

You're yourself (duh) and you have to detect and fix neurons causing mental disorders in a patient. That's about it, I played it with Keyboard & Mouse, it was 4 minutes long, to perfect on first run. The gameplay mechanic is very simple, you're riding a roller coaster and you have to aim (with your head if you have an Oculus Rift or with your Mouse if you don't) red targets that appear around you, as you advance.

Not bad for a demo, it's free and also, less than 250MB, so I think it’s an interesting experience.

★★★☆☆ | It was OK
voteText: 45 of 51 people (88%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
A short and fun little VR demo, but it was clearly made for DK1 or GearVR and so it's not a flawless experience on DK2.

+Simple graphics work well with Rift DK2
+Great performance
+No gamepad required
+Looks strange and otherwordly

-No positional tracking
-No particles floating around
-Very short (about 2-3 minutes)
-On-Rails movement a bit awkward, could be smoother
-When it loads, everything freezes which is disorienting, bad VR practice


If it cost money I don't think I would recommend it but as it's free, why the heck not!
I have yet to see a perfect VR demo anyway, and this is better than most.
voteText: 27 of 31 people (87%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Awesome Oculus VR Experience
This is a short little virtual reality demo and game that did awesome things to my brain. The game is a roller coaster ride of dysfunctional neuron destruction. You literally ride a rail through a brain shooting dysfunctional cells by looking at them.

I like how the whole experience is controlled using the Oculus Rift, right down to menu selection.  Best of all, no nausea.

YouTube : Oculus Rift InMind VR

Hope you like it!

reviewText:
Before the game starts, you get to choose between two options: play with keyboard and mouse or play with Oculus Rift. I do not have the latter so I chose the former.

You are taken on a short adventure into the human brain, and you are the chosen one who has to heal a depressed patient by looking at his disordered neurons.

And so the journey begins, and you can admire the view inside the human brain. It is a short game which rewards you at the end based on how many neurons you got.

Try it. It isn't long, but offers insight in how VR-games could work. They have another game in work which will take place in human cells.

reviewText:
This product was a steam recommendation though I don't have Oculus VR,

Cons
---
Extremely short; ends the moment you've gotten into it

Should've used a real VO actress with a vocoder, instead of a synthesized voice

Extremely short

Cart/chariot obstructs vision

Could use more post-processing & effects

Pros
---
Optimized graphics allow to a smooth, lag-free experience

Visually & graphically impressive

===
I would definately give this a go, again, when I get a VR headset

8.5/10

reviewText:
InMind VR has a really awesome concept, and I hope games like these actually contribute in the development of VRMMO's (Yes, I've seen SAO and I love it. Problem?)

There is one major thing I hate about InMind VR, however. It's really an on-rails game (the type of which I despise) and doesn't give you much freedom in terms of movement or anything else really. You just launch the game and it throws you straight into the brain to fix a Human's neurons.

HOWEVER, despite that major shortcoming, InMind VR has stunning visuals of the insides of a Human brain and shows us, those who aren't doctors, how the Human brain looks like from a really tiny level. Even with a severe limitation, it just lets you truly feel that you're inside the brain and see each thought process, each signal being sent or received by neurons.

Perfect for when you're high too.

reviewText:
This short concept game is perfectly executed:
It plays perfectly on Oculus DK2, there is no lag and the visuals suit the headset perfectly.
The scoring system could easily be taken forwards to making a full game in the classic mobile game sense.
The motion slowly ramps up in diffuculty, with the head look tracking perfectly suiting the genre and the late game requiring a little planning an forethought.

I look forward to a multi-level version of this game that I would put mobile-game money down for.

reviewText:
I like the execution of the idea in mind, no pun intended. This is a very smooth VR experience and simple to understand what you are supposed to do. The visuals are also nice to just sit back and look at everything going on around yourself. Overall I enjoyed this little demo and I would like to see where this goes in the future! Great job to all involved in making this happen.



As a side note, this ran perfect under linux Arch with no crashes or noticable bugs and the configuration was straight forward, no issues at all!
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Fun, fun game!

I don't know what other VR games do this, but the aiming reticle and wind-up trigger in the HMD is nothing short of intoxicating!  For the first time since getting the DK2, I had a sense of empowerment (read: Unfair advantage. License to pwn!) which I have never experienced before. I didn't think that gyrating my big melon around could be an advantage, but it really does bring something to the table as far as VR is concerned. Yay, neck muscles!

Entirely too short for how much fun it is.  I'm ready to pay for more! Right now, it's like an amusement park attraction--short burst of a high-quality sensation.  It reminds me of Buzz Lightyear's Space Ranger Spin or similar shooting-gallery ride, though it's much less difficult (Cracked 50/50 on the first try!) and way more gratifying than those sorts of rides for the short time you are in there. Plus, no need for a Fast Pass!

Don't underestimate the headphones either. It really solidifies the mood.

9/10 - Launch bugs.

reviewText:
Fantastic.

I have purchased an Oculus Rift for my university project (not out of my own pocket I might add) and this was the first game I played. This game is great for demonstrating the potential for the virtual gaming industry. It is also a very smoothe prorgam to help ease the user into virtual reality, rather than jumping straight in into the likes of a flight simulator.. (Which was the second program I ran)

Virtual reality first timer? Give this a go first.

Used virtual reality before? Still worth a shot to see if you can get full marks.

reviewText: When this game says it's short, it means it. I beat the game in about four minutes. As far as gameplay goes, it was extremely basic (I played it on my laptop rather than a VR console). Movement is done for you, taking you along a pre-designated track (very much like a Disney ride) through a human brain. Move the mouse to look at bad intersections in the human brain, and the game shoots for you.\nThis game's strength is its visual appeal. This game is BEAUTIFUL. I can't stress enough how nice this game is just to look at. The colors and patterns are wonderful, and I'd imagine it'd be even better on a VR console. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone and everyone. And even if you don't like it, it only takes four minutes.

reviewText: This game is less than good. Now, I will give you perspective as to what I was expecting and what came out. I was expecting an open minded (pun intended) kind of game. To the sense of not only just floating around a computer generated game but be able to pick things to learn about if you wanted. It had neither of those. You are on a guided course and are given direction. You complete a small and simple task by looking at stuff. Thats it. Granted the surroundings are pretty cool. Getting to see all of the diffrent nurons inside the brain to a degree, but like I said, I was hoping it was going to be more of I could explore and look at what I want when I want. Not just look at specific nurons that are cause the patient you're inside to have depresson. Moving from one area to the next seeing the same thing over and over again. It didn't cost  anything but it wasn't time well wasted either. The other draw back aside from the gameplay is the narration. They put no time into any voice over. It was a computer generated voice saying words that had been typed into a computer. So there was no flow, or over all tone. Even words with more than one syllable came out choppy.\nI wouldn't recomend this game if you're looking for an educational explore the diffrent parts of the brain experience.\n

reviewText:
Cool idea. I look forward to seeing what else comes.

Now though if you get motion sick prep before hand. I don't, but there were a few moments that you move so quick that it's rough. Even if you don't get motion sick I'd suggest sitting down.

Only quarrel is even after closing it out I noticed my play time still ticking up until I restarted SteamVR. Not sure why.

Give it a shot just be ready for possible motion sickness.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: A very simple and neat demonstration of VR's potential as an educational tool. While there's pretty much nothing educational going on in a look-and-click game, it does give a sense of things to come when software sends kids hurtling through the body as a means of teaching biology/chemistry/physics. And if you just got your VR device I suggest checking it out for the 5 minute experience. I hope that when I have kids they'll be able to learn in similar enviornments, as I would have cared far more in science class if I could hop from one neuron to the next.

reviewText: This is a pretty amazong experience in VR. I really like to looking mechanic and shooting as objects are coming at you, the game is challenging and there seems like quite a bit of gamelay from what ive seen so far.\n\nAt times the looking for aim mechinic gets  abit tiresome, but overall I cant really think of abetter way of aiming unless you make it only for the vive with motion controls. maybe that could be added in a future version.

reviewText: The concept for this game is really cool, you are shrunk down to the size where you can go inside somebodys brain and shoot stuff thats inside thier head. It reminds me of that movie fantastic voyage where they all get in a ship and then try to fix some president or something.\n\nThe game mechanics are basically a on rails shooter, which is fine. I like games liek that and it seems to work in VR, which is what I was playing, so I can't comment on the flat version, but i guess thats good too becuase in VR its great. Hope they make more games like this, did not make me sick.

reviewText: It is pretty cool.  However, the voice" needs some proofreading.  There are some points where it is clear that the original language was not English.  Nothing wrong with that
date: but it could use some work from a native English speaker.  It would also be nice if there were more than just the one "level"."

reviewText:
Basic on-rails 'educational' 'shooter'. 2/10

- Causes motion sickness.
- No difficulty. Entire gameplay consists of looking at things until they turn green.
- No educational value.
- No way to exit application on vive without taking headset off (controllers are invisible).

+ Decent graphics.
+ Short enough that you can complete it without vomiting (I've 100% completed the game).
